subsc: Ports, waterways and shipping,Roads and highways,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and institutional development
            impacts are substantial. Regardless of success, key lessons
            convey that: 1) by and large, raising port services levels
            to international standards, is not usually feasible within
            the public sector framework. Therefore, it is essential that
            an appropriate institutional framework involve private
            sector participation, to sustain improvements to port
            systems, by creating domestic competition, leading to
            regional competition, and/or concession agreements, forcible
            enough to obtain regulations protecting public interests,
            but under an appropriate institutional framework; 2)
            divestiture programs should be undertaken by institutions
            not related to the enterprise undergoing restructuring,
            while the privatization policy should be central to the
            macroeconomic policy framework, to ensure an objective
            approach to divestiture, and in turn, provide an appropriate
            political backing to the process; 3) changing circumstances,
            or project performance itself, may lead to unforeseen
            negative results, such as waste of resources on components
            with negligible impacts, but a flexible project design may
            prevent, and/or facilitate such resources to more critical
            investments; and, 4) given the superb project coordination,
            the complexity of the project did not preclude success,
            however, records management should be considered at project design.
